elements.content: Control over the degree of interpenetration within metal–organic frameworks has important implications for the application of these materials in numerous areas ranging from gas storage to chemical separations. In this work, the degree of interpenetration was controlled in a series of three Co2+ frameworks with the redox-active tris­(4-(pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl)­amine (NPy3) ligand, where the steric bulk of the dicarboxylate coligand (1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc), 2,5-dimethyl-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (dmbdc), or 2,3,5,6-tetramethyl-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (tmbdc)) was increased by the addition of methyl groups to the phenyl core. The use of less sterically hindered carboxylates (bdc, dmbdc) resulted in 3-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional (3D) networks, while use of the tmbdc ligand resulted in a 3D non-interpenetrated structure. The redox activity of the NPy3 ligand was retained within the framework as elucidated from electrochemical and spectral measurements.
elements.clean_text: Control over the degree of interpenetration within metal-organic frameworks has important implications for the application of these materials in numerous areas ranging from gas storage to chemical separations. In this work, the degree of interpenetration was controlled in a series of three Co2+ frameworks with the redox-active tris(4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)amine (NPy3) ligand, where the steric bulk of the dicarboxylate coligand (1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc), 2,5-dimethyl-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (dmbdc), or 2,3,5,6-tetramethyl-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (tmbdc)) was increased by the addition of methyl groups to the phenyl core. The use of less sterically hindered carboxylates (bdc, dmbdc) resulted in 3-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional (3D) networks, while use of the tmbdc ligand resulted in a 3D non-interpenetrated structure. The redox activity of the NPy3 ligand was retained within the framework as elucidated from electrochemical and spectral measurements.

elements.content: The degree of interpenetration in a series of three Co2+ frameworks with the redox-active tris­(4-(pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl)­amine ligand was controlled by varying the steric bulk of the dicarboxylate coligand. The redox activity of the NPy3 ligand was retained within the framework as elucidated from electrochemical and spectral measurements.
elements.clean_text: The degree of interpenetration in a series of three Co2+ frameworks with the redox-active tris(4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)amine ligand was controlled by varying the steric bulk of the dicarboxylate coligand. The redox activity of the NPy3 ligand was retained within the framework as elucidated from electrochemical and spectral measurements.

elements.content: There has been a significant focus on the design of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) for applications in numerous areas including gas capture and storage, as cathode materials in lithium ion batteries, and in chemical separations and catalysis. The ability to control the pore size, surface area, and density has important implications for the resultant application of framework materials which often requires specific properties to be optimized for efficient performance. Large pore sizes and high porosities are desired in gas capture and storage, while small pore sizes and interpenetrated systems afford greater control over the selectivity in chemical separations.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

There has been a significant focus on the design of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) for applications in numerous areas including gas capture and storage, as cathode materials in lithium ion batteries, and in chemical separations and catalysis. The ability to control the pore size, surface area, and density has important implications for the resultant application of framework materials which often requires specific properties to be optimized for efficient performance. Large pore sizes and high porosities are desired in gas capture and storage, while small pore sizes and interpenetrated systems afford greater control over the selectivity in chemical separations.

elements.content: A number of strategies have been employed to control the degree of interpenetration in network systems which include varying the concentration of reaction mixtures, the length of organic linkers, and/or the presence of bulky substituents or pendant groups as well as template-directed control methods. Arguably, the use of bulky substituents offers the most systematic, synthetically accessible, and predictable means of controlling interpenetration. An elegant example by Li et al. demonstrated the effect of increasing the steric bulk on the pendant substituent of terpyridine ligands. As the 4-isopropylphenyl pendant group (which formed a 4-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional (3D) network) was changed to the more sterically bulky biphenyl group a single non-interpenetrated network was formed.
elements.clean_text: A number of strategies have been employed to control the degree of interpenetration in network systems which include varying the concentration of reaction mixtures, the length of organic linkers, and/or the presence of bulky substituents or pendant groups as well as template-directed control methods. Arguably, the use of bulky substituents offers the most systematic, synthetically accessible, and predictable means of controlling interpenetration. An elegant example by Li et al. demonstrated the effect of increasing the steric bulk on the pendant substituent of terpyridine ligands. As the 4-isopropylphenyl pendant group (which formed a 4-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional (3D) network) was changed to the more sterically bulky biphenyl group a single non-interpenetrated network was formed.

elements.content: The triarylamine core has previously been demonstrated to exhibit a highly reversible one electron oxidation to form its triarylamine radical cation, and MOFs synthesized with this core have been shown to retain these redox-active properties. The incorporation of a redox-active ligand allows for the development of multifunctional materials that are capable of changing their properties as a function of the redox state.
elements.clean_text: The triarylamine core has previously been demonstrated to exhibit a highly reversible one electron oxidation to form its triarylamine radical cation, and MOFs synthesized with this core have been shown to retain these redox-active properties. The incorporation of a redox-active ligand allows for the development of multifunctional materials that are capable of changing their properties as a function of the redox state.

elements.content: In the present work, a series of three Co2+ frameworks based on the tris­(4-(pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl)­amine (NPy3) ligand were investigated, where the steric bulk of a dicarboxylate coligand was systematically increased by the addition of methyl groups on the phenyl ring. Of particular interest was the modulation of the degree of interpenetration within the series, and the resultant electrochemical and spectral properties of the frameworks as a function of their redox state. The combination of the structural control afforded over the degree of interpenetration coupled with the incorporation of a redox-active ligand imparting multifunctionality provides a powerful platform for the synthesis of functional materials that may be tailored for applications in chemical sensing and electrocatalysis.
elements.clean_text: In the present work, a series of three Co2+ frameworks based on the tris(4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)amine (NPy3) ligand were investigated, where the steric bulk of a dicarboxylate coligand was systematically increased by the addition of methyl groups on the phenyl ring. Of particular interest was the modulation of the degree of interpenetration within the series, and the resultant electrochemical and spectral properties of the frameworks as a function of their redox state. The combination of the structural control afforded over the degree of interpenetration coupled with the incorporation of a redox-active ligand imparting multifunctionality provides a powerful platform for the synthesis of functional materials that may be tailored for applications in chemical sensing and electrocatalysis.

elements.content: The three Co2+ frameworks containing NPy3 and a given dicarboxylate coligand (1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc), 2,5-dimethyl-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (dmbdc), or 2,3,5,6-tetramethyl-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (tmbdc)) were synthesized by heating these ligands with cobalt­(II) chloride hexahydrate in a mixture of DMF/MeOH at 60 °C. The frameworks were obtained as maroon needle-like crystals ([Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n and [Co­(NPy3)­(dmbdc)­Cl] n ) or small dark purple prisms ([Co­(NPy3)­(tmbdc)] n ) (ESI). The crystals were air sensitive and exhibited a color change from maroon/purple to orange/yellow upon extended exposure to air which resulted in their decomposition.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structure

The three Co2+ frameworks containing NPy3 and a given dicarboxylate coligand (1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc), 2,5-dimethyl-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (dmbdc), or 2,3,5,6-tetramethyl-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (tmbdc)) were synthesized by heating these ligands with cobalt(II) chloride hexahydrate in a mixture of DMF/MeOH at 60 °C. The frameworks were obtained as maroon needle-like crystals ([Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n  and [Co(NPy3)(dmbdc)Cl] n ) or small dark purple prisms ([Co(NPy3)(tmbdc)] n ) (ESI). The crystals were air sensitive and exhibited a color change from maroon/purple to orange/yellow upon extended exposure to air which resulted in their decomposition.

elements.content: The solid state structure of the [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n framework was solved and refined in the monoclinic space group P21/n. The Co2+ center displayed a distorted octahedral coordination sphere consisting of two oxygen atoms from one bdc ligand bound in a bidentate fashion, and two chlorine atoms and two nitrogen atoms from two separate NPy3 ligands (a). The bond angles deviate from the expected 90° for an octahedral coordination sphere; for example, the O1–Co1–O2 bond angle was 62.13° due to the bidentate binding mode of the two oxygen atoms from the bdc ligand to the metal center. The two chlorides form a bridge with a μ-coordination mode between two cobalt centers. The NPy3 ligand exhibits a propeller-like orientation, which is consistent with previously reported structures of molecules containing the triphenylamine core.
elements.clean_text: The solid state structure of the [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n  framework was solved and refined in the monoclinic space group P21/n. The Co2+ center displayed a distorted octahedral coordination sphere consisting of two oxygen atoms from one bdc ligand bound in a bidentate fashion, and two chlorine atoms and two nitrogen atoms from two separate NPy3 ligands (a). The bond angles deviate from the expected 90° for an octahedral coordination sphere; for example, the O1-Co1-O2 bond angle was 62.13° due to the bidentate binding mode of the two oxygen atoms from the bdc ligand to the metal center. The two chlorides form a bridge with a μ-coordination mode between two cobalt centers. The NPy3 ligand exhibits a propeller-like orientation, which is consistent with previously reported structures of molecules containing the triphenylamine core.

elements.content: (a) Coordination mode around the Co2+ center, (b) three interpenetrated networks along the c axis, and (c) the 2D network containing the NPy3 ligand coordinated to Co2+ centers and the bridging bdc ligand forming the 3D network of the [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n framework.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination mode around the Co2+ center, (b) three interpenetrated networks along the c axis, and (c) the 2D network containing the NPy3 ligand coordinated to Co2+ centers and the bridging bdc ligand forming the 3D network of the [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n  framework.

elements.content: The [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n framework consists of three interpenetrated networks (b). The topology of the framework can be described as three interpenetrating simple cubic networks. The Co2Cl2 unit serves as a six-connecting node linked by two-connecting NPy3 units to form a two-dimensional (2D) network with a (4,4)- topology in a square grid network. The Co2Cl2 nodes are further linked by bdc acting as pillars to yield a 3D network with the same topology as that of the simple cubic net (c). A similar Co2+ framework with NPy3 and a bdc coligand was reported by Zheng et al., which differed from the structure of [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n due to the coordination of a water molecule to the Co2+ center, resulting in the two oxygens on the bdc ligand binding to two separate Co2+ centers in a monodentate fashion. Using the SQUEEZE function in PLATON, a void accessible volume of 7.1% was obtained. This corresponds to the mass loss observed due to two methanol molecules (calculated 9%), in the thermal gravimetric analysis below 100 °C (ESI).
elements.clean_text: The [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n  framework consists of three interpenetrated networks (b). The topology of the framework can be described as three interpenetrating simple cubic networks. The Co2Cl2 unit serves as a six-connecting node linked by two-connecting NPy3 units to form a two-dimensional (2D) network with a (4,4)- topology in a square grid network. The Co2Cl2 nodes are further linked by bdc acting as pillars to yield a 3D network with the same topology as that of the simple cubic net (c). A similar Co2+ framework with NPy3 and a bdc coligand was reported by Zheng et al., which differed from the structure of [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n  due to the coordination of a water molecule to the Co2+ center, resulting in the two oxygens on the bdc ligand binding to two separate Co2+ centers in a monodentate fashion. Using the SQUEEZE function in PLATON, a void accessible volume of 7.1% was obtained. This corresponds to the mass loss observed due to two methanol molecules (calculated 9%), in the thermal gravimetric analysis below 100 °C (ESI).

elements.content: The solid state structure of the [Co­(NPy3)­(dmbdc)­Cl] n framework was solved and refined in the monoclinic space group P21/n and was isostructural to [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n (ESI). Again, the dmbdc ligands act as pillars between the 2D zigzag layers containing the NPy3 ligand and Co2+ to form the 3D simple cubic net structure. The [Co­(NPy3)­(dmbdc)­Cl] n framework was also 3-fold interpenetrated but interestingly exhibited a significantly higher void accessible volume of 18.4% as calculated by PLATON when compared to the [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n structure (7.1%). The increase in the void accessible volume was presumably due to the increased steric bulk of the dmbdc ligand where the methyl groups may aid in holding the 3-fold interpenetrated networks apart from each other. TGA revealed a ∼15% mass loss <150 °C, corresponding to the loss of methanol from the pores of the framework (ESI).
elements.clean_text: The solid state structure of the [Co(NPy3)(dmbdc)Cl] n  framework was solved and refined in the monoclinic space group P21/n and was isostructural to [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n  (ESI). Again, the dmbdc ligands act as pillars between the 2D zigzag layers containing the NPy3 ligand and Co2+ to form the 3D simple cubic net structure. The [Co(NPy3)(dmbdc)Cl] n  framework was also 3-fold interpenetrated but interestingly exhibited a significantly higher void accessible volume of 18.4% as calculated by PLATON when compared to the [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n  structure (7.1%). The increase in the void accessible volume was presumably due to the increased steric bulk of the dmbdc ligand where the methyl groups may aid in holding the 3-fold interpenetrated networks apart from each other. TGA revealed a ~15% mass loss <150 °C, corresponding to the loss of methanol from the pores of the framework (ESI).

elements.content: The [Co­(NPy3)­(tmbdc)] n structure was solved and refined in the monoclinic Cc space group and was significantly different from that obtained for [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n and [Co­(NPy3)­(dmbdc)­Cl] n due to the increased steric bulk of the methyl groups on the tmbdc ligand. The asymmetric unit of the framework contains three distinct Co2+ centers (a) where two of the centers (Co1 and Co2) contained a distorted octahedral coordination sphere with three nitrogen donors from three distinct NPy3 ligands and three oxygen donors. Two of the oxygen donors from the same dicarboxylate ligand are bound in a bidentate manner with an angle of 59.86°. The remaining oxygen donor is bound in a monodentate manner with the second oxygen of the carboxylate group remaining unbound. The third Co2+ center (Co3) contains a square pyramidal coordination sphere with three nitrogen donors from three distinct NPy3 ligands and two oxygen donors bound in a monodentate fashion from two distinct dicarboxylate ligands. The other oxygen donor from these dicarboxylate ligands remains unbound, presumably due to the steric bulk of the methyl groups of the dicarboxylate ligand. The Flack parameter value refined to 0.440(6) which describes the presence of an inversion twin where the fraction of the inversion related component is 0.4.
elements.clean_text: The [Co(NPy3)(tmbdc)] n  structure was solved and refined in the monoclinic Cc space group and was significantly different from that obtained for [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n  and [Co(NPy3)(dmbdc)Cl] n  due to the increased steric bulk of the methyl groups on the tmbdc ligand. The asymmetric unit of the framework contains three distinct Co2+ centers (a) where two of the centers (Co1 and Co2) contained a distorted octahedral coordination sphere with three nitrogen donors from three distinct NPy3 ligands and three oxygen donors. Two of the oxygen donors from the same dicarboxylate ligand are bound in a bidentate manner with an angle of 59.86°. The remaining oxygen donor is bound in a monodentate manner with the second oxygen of the carboxylate group remaining unbound. The third Co2+ center (Co3) contains a square pyramidal coordination sphere with three nitrogen donors from three distinct NPy3 ligands and two oxygen donors bound in a monodentate fashion from two distinct dicarboxylate ligands. The other oxygen donor from these dicarboxylate ligands remains unbound, presumably due to the steric bulk of the methyl groups of the dicarboxylate ligand. The Flack parameter value refined to 0.440(6) which describes the presence of an inversion twin where the fraction of the inversion related component is 0.4.

elements.content: Solid state structure of the [Co­(NPy3)­(tmbdc)] n framework showing the (a) asymmetric unit, (b) view along the a axis, (c) three interpenetrating (10,3b) nets comprising of the Co centers and NPy3 ligands, where the blue and red nets are crystallographically related and (d) the single network created by linkage of the interpenetrating (10,3b) nets through the Co centers by the tmbdc ligand.
elements.clean_text: 2  Solid state structure of the [Co(NPy3)(tmbdc)] n  framework showing the (a) asymmetric unit, (b) view along the a axis, (c) three interpenetrating (10,3b) nets comprising of the Co centers and NPy3 ligands, where the blue and red nets are crystallographically related and (d) the single network created by linkage of the interpenetrating (10,3b) nets through the Co centers by the tmbdc ligand.

elements.content: The framework consists of a single non-interpenetrated 3D network which contains the four metal centers linked in an alternate fashion with the NPy3 ligand and the tmbdc ligand to yield a hexagonal-shaped cavity (ESI). Small pores can be observed when the framework is viewed down the a axis (b). The Co centers and NPy3 ligand comprise three interpenetrating (10,3b) nets, where two of the networks are crystallographically related (comprised of the Co1 and Co3 centers) (c). The dmbdc ligand links pairs of Co centers together yielding a single network of 5-connecting nodes (Co centers) and 3-connecting NPy3 ligands (d).
elements.clean_text: The framework consists of a single non-interpenetrated 3D network which contains the four metal centers linked in an alternate fashion with the NPy3 ligand and the tmbdc ligand to yield a hexagonal-shaped cavity (ESI). Small pores can be observed when the framework is viewed down the a axis (b). The Co centers and NPy3 ligand comprise three interpenetrating (10,3b) nets, where two of the networks are crystallographically related (comprised of the Co1 and Co3 centers) (c). The dmbdc ligand links pairs of Co centers together yielding a single network of 5-connecting nodes (Co centers) and 3-connecting NPy3 ligands (d).

elements.content: Using the SQUEEZE function in PLATON, a void accessible volume of 40% was calculated. Unsurprisingly, the [Co­(NPy3)­(tmbdc)] n framework exhibited a higher void accessible volume than [CoNPy3­(bdc)­Cl] n and [CoNPy3­(dmbdc)­Cl] n due to its single non-interpenetrated network structure. The larger void accessible volume correspondingly resulted in a larger mass loss in the TGA for the [Co­(NPy3)­(tmbdc)] n framework when compared to [CoNPy3­(bdc)­Cl] n and [CoNPy3­(dmbdc)­Cl] n at temperatures below 150 °C (ESI).
elements.clean_text: Using the SQUEEZE function in PLATON, a void accessible volume of 40% was calculated. Unsurprisingly, the [Co(NPy3)(tmbdc)] n  framework exhibited a higher void accessible volume than [CoNPy3(bdc)Cl] n  and [CoNPy3(dmbdc)Cl] n  due to its single non-interpenetrated network structure. The larger void accessible volume correspondingly resulted in a larger mass loss in the TGA for the [Co(NPy3)(tmbdc)] n  framework when compared to [CoNPy3(bdc)Cl] n  and [CoNPy3(dmbdc)Cl] n  at temperatures below 150 °C (ESI).

elements.content: The redox properties of the Co2+ frameworks were investigated using solid state cyclic voltammetry experiments in [(n-C4H9)4N]­PF6/CH3CN electrolyte (). For all frameworks, one broad oxidative process was observed at ∼1.0 V vs Fc/Fc+, which was resolved into two processes at 0.9 and 1.1 vs Fc/Fc+ at faster scan rates (>200 mV/s) in the [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n and [Co­(NPy3)­(tmbdc)­Cl] n frameworks. These oxidation processes were assigned to the one electron oxidation of the triarylamine core to its radical cation state with concurrent oxidation of the Co2+ center to Co3+. The broad reduction process observed at ∼ −2.0 V vs Fc/Fc+ was due to reduction of the Co3+ formed in the forward sweep to Co2+ and becomes increasingly prominent with increasing scan rates. At slow scan rates, it is likely that the framework has sufficient time to decompose, resulting in the absence of a corresponding reduction peak.
elements.clean_text:
Redox and Spectral Properties

The redox properties of the Co2+ frameworks were investigated using solid state cyclic voltammetry experiments in [(n-C4H9)4N]PF6/CH3CN electrolyte (). For all frameworks, one broad oxidative process was observed at ~1.0 V vs Fc/Fc+, which was resolved into two processes at 0.9 and 1.1 vs Fc/Fc+ at faster scan rates (>200 mV/s) in the [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n  and [Co(NPy3)(tmbdc)Cl] n  frameworks. These oxidation processes were assigned to the one electron oxidation of the triarylamine core to its radical cation state with concurrent oxidation of the Co2+ center to Co3+. The broad reduction process observed at ~ -2.0 V vs Fc/Fc+ was due to reduction of the Co3+ formed in the forward sweep to Co2+ and becomes increasingly prominent with increasing scan rates. At slow scan rates, it is likely that the framework has sufficient time to decompose, resulting in the absence of a corresponding reduction peak.

elements.content: Solid state cyclic voltammograms of (a) [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n , (b) [Co­(NPy3)­(dmbdc)­Cl] n , and (c) [Co­(NPy3)­(tmbdc)] n in 0.1 M [(n-C4H9)4N]­PF6/CH3CN electrolyte at scan rates in the range 100–1000 mV/s. Potentials are reported vs the Fc/Fc+ couple where the arrow indicates the direction of the forward scan.
elements.clean_text: 3  Solid state cyclic voltammograms of (a) [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n , (b) [Co(NPy3)(dmbdc)Cl] n , and (c) [Co(NPy3)(tmbdc)] n  in 0.1 M [(n-C4H9)4N]PF6/CH3CN electrolyte at scan rates in the range 100-1000 mV/s. Potentials are reported vs the Fc/Fc+ couple where the arrow indicates the direction of the forward scan.

elements.content: The solid state spectra over the UV/vis/NIR range of 5000–40000 cm–1 for the Co2+ frameworks revealed several distinguishing features. The broad bands observed in the NIR region (5000–12500 cm–1) were attributed to d–d transitions of the d7 Co2+ center. The band at ∼27000 cm–1 in all frameworks was assigned to the Co2+4 T 1g(F) → 4 T 1g(P) transition, where the band has complex envelopes as a number of transitions to doublet excited states occur in the same region (which acquire intensity by spin–orbit coupling). This band is consistent with the octahedral coordination geometry observed in the solid state structure as transitions for tetrahedral Co2+ would be expected to occur at a lower energy. The bands at energies above 25 000 cm–1 arise from a combination of charge transfer transitions of the Co2+ center along with π to π* transitions of the aromatic moieties present in the ligands.
elements.clean_text: The solid state spectra over the UV/vis/NIR range of 5000-40000 cm-1 for the Co2+ frameworks revealed several distinguishing features. The broad bands observed in the NIR region (5000-12500 cm-1) were attributed to d-d transitions of the d7 Co2+ center. The band at ~27000 cm-1 in all frameworks was assigned to the Co2+4 T 1g(F) → 4 T 1g(P) transition, where the band has complex envelopes as a number of transitions to doublet excited states occur in the same region (which acquire intensity by spin-orbit coupling). This band is consistent with the octahedral coordination geometry observed in the solid state structure as transitions for tetrahedral Co2+ would be expected to occur at a lower energy. The bands at energies above 25000 cm-1 arise from a combination of charge transfer transitions of the Co2+ center along with π to π* transitions of the aromatic moieties present in the ligands.

elements.content: The frameworks exhibited a color change from maroon/purple to yellow/orange upon exposure to air over the course of a few hours or upon grinding. This color change was ascribed to oxidation of the Co2+ center to Co3+ and resulted in a red shift in the band at ∼27 000 cm–1 (). Two bands in the visible range were observed for the octahedral Co3+ metal center due to transitions from the 1A1g ground state to the excited 1T1g and 1T2g states: the band at 17000 cm–1 can be assigned to the 1A1g to 1T1g transition and the band at 21 000 cm–1 to the 1A1g to 1T2g transition. The bands observed in the NIR region for the oxidized frameworks were consistent with the d–d transitions for octahedral d6 Co3+ centers. Interestingly, upon oxidation of the [Co­(NPy3)­(dmbdc)­Cl] n framework, the envelope of bands in the region 15000–24000 cm–1 decreased, indicating a loss of the charge-transfer interactions between the Co2+ metal center and NPy3 ligand.
elements.clean_text: The frameworks exhibited a color change from maroon/purple to yellow/orange upon exposure to air over the course of a few hours or upon grinding. This color change was ascribed to oxidation of the Co2+ center to Co3+ and resulted in a red shift in the band at ~27000 cm-1 (). Two bands in the visible range were observed for the octahedral Co3+ metal center due to transitions from the 1A1g ground state to the excited 1T1g and 1T2g states: the band at 17000 cm-1 can be assigned to the 1A1g to 1T1g transition and the band at 21000 cm-1 to the 1A1g to 1T2g transition. The bands observed in the NIR region for the oxidized frameworks were consistent with the d-d transitions for octahedral d6 Co3+ centers. Interestingly, upon oxidation of the [Co(NPy3)(dmbdc)Cl] n  framework, the envelope of bands in the region 15000-24000 cm-1 decreased, indicating a loss of the charge-transfer interactions between the Co2+ metal center and NPy3 ligand.

elements.content: Solid state UV/vis/NIR spectrum of [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n , [Co­(NPy3)­(dmbdc)­Cl] n , [Co­(NPy3)­(tmbdc)] n , and their oxidized analogues over the range 5000–40000 cm–1.
elements.clean_text: 4  Solid state UV/vis/NIR spectrum of [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n , [Co(NPy3)(dmbdc)Cl] n , [Co(NPy3)(tmbdc)] n , and their oxidized analogues over the range 5000-40000 cm-1.

elements.content: Control over the degree of interpenetration within a series of Co2+ frameworks containing the electroactive NPy3 ligand was afforded by increasing the steric bulk on the dicarboxylate coligand. Use of the bulky tmbdc ligand resulted in the formation of a single non-interpenetrated network with an increased void accessible volume when compared to the 3-fold 3D interpenetrated structures obtained with the bdc and dmbdc ligands. The incorporation of a redox-active triarylamine ligand afforded electroactivity to the resultant frameworks, where the accessible redox states were able to be elucidated using electrochemical experiments. The ability to control the degree of interpenetration in redox-active framework materials through the incorporation of a redox-inactive coligand has important implications for the synthesis of multifunctional materials specially tailored for applications in separations, chemical sensing and catalysis.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Control over the degree of interpenetration within a series of Co2+ frameworks containing the electroactive NPy3 ligand was afforded by increasing the steric bulk on the dicarboxylate coligand. Use of the bulky tmbdc ligand resulted in the formation of a single non-interpenetrated network with an increased void accessible volume when compared to the 3-fold 3D interpenetrated structures obtained with the bdc and dmbdc ligands. The incorporation of a redox-active triarylamine ligand afforded electroactivity to the resultant frameworks, where the accessible redox states were able to be elucidated using electrochemical experiments. The ability to control the degree of interpenetration in redox-active framework materials through the incorporation of a redox-inactive coligand has important implications for the synthesis of multifunctional materials specially tailored for applications in separations, chemical sensing and catalysis.

elements.content: Distilled and degassed acetonitrile (dried over CaH2) was used for all electrochemical experiments. DMF was dried over activated CaSO4 then distilled under reduced pressure. Microanalyses were carried out at the Chemical Analysis Facility – Elemental Analysis Service in the Department of Chemistry and Biomolecular Science at Macquarie University, Australia. The tris­(4-(pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl)­amine (NPy3) ligand was synthesized according to literature procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Considerations

Distilled and degassed acetonitrile (dried over CaH2) was used for all electrochemical experiments. DMF was dried over activated CaSO4 then distilled under reduced pressure. Microanalyses were carried out at the Chemical Analysis Facility - Elemental Analysis Service in the Department of Chemistry and Biomolecular Science at Macquarie University, Australia. The tris(4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)amine (NPy3) ligand was synthesized according to literature procedures.

elements.content: NPy3 (5 mg, 1.05 × 10–5 mol), terephalic acid (5.23 mg, 3.00 × 10–5 mol), and cobalt­(II) chloride hexahydrate (7.5 mg, 3.15 × 10–5 mol) were dissolved in a mixture of DMF (5 mL) and methanol (5 mL). The reaction mixture was heated to 60 °C at a rate of 0.1 °C/min and held at 60 °C for 48 h before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min to yield the framework, [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n , as maroon needle-like crystals (5.4 mg, 72%). Elemental analysis: Found C, 65.35; H, 4.95 and N, 8.01; Calculated for C37H26Cl­CoN4O2­·2CH3OH: C, 65.32; H, 4.78; N, 7.81%.

Synthesis of Frameworks

[CoNPy3(bdc)Cl] n  Framework

NPy3 (5 mg, 1.05 × 10-5 mol), terephalic acid (5.23 mg, 3.00 × 10-5 mol), and cobalt(II) chloride hexahydrate (7.5 mg, 3.15 × 10-5 mol) were dissolved in a mixture of DMF (5 mL) and methanol (5 mL). The reaction mixture was heated to 60 °C at a rate of 0.1 °C/min and held at 60 °C for 48 h before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min to yield the framework, [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n , as maroon needle-like crystals (5.4 mg, 72%). The reaction mixture was heated to 60 °C at a rate of 0.1 °C/min and held at 60 °C for 48 h before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min to yield the framework, [Co­(NPy3)­(dmbdc)­Cl] n , as maroon needle-like crystals (12 mg, 86%). Elemental analysis: Found C, 65.01; H, 4.70 and N, 8.69; Calculated for C38H24ClCoN4O2­·0.85DMF­·1.77CH3OH: C, 65.01; H, 4.77; N, 8.69%.

[CoNPy3(dmbdc)Cl] n  Framework

NPy3 (10 mg, 2.10 × 10-5 mol), 2,5-dimethylterephalic acid (12.2 mg, 7.30 × 10-5 mol), and cobalt(II) chloride hexahydrate (15.0 mg, 7.30 × 10-5 mol) were dissolved in a mixture of DMF (5 mL) and methanol (5 mL). The reaction mixture was heated to 60 °C at a rate of 0.1 °C/min and held at 60 °C for 48 h before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min to yield the framework, [Co(NPy3)(dmbdc)Cl] n , as maroon needle-like crystals (12 mg, 86%). elements.content: NPy3 (5 mg, 1.05 × 10–5 mol), 2,3,5,6-tetramethylterephalic acid (7.00 mg, 3.15 × 10–5 mol), and cobalt­(II) chloride hexahydrate (7.5 mg, 3.15 × 10–5 mol) were dissolved in a mixture of DMF (5 mL) and methanol (5 mL). The reaction mixture was heated to 60 °C at a rate of 0.1 °C/min and held at 60 °C for 48 h before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min to yield the framework, [Co­(NPy3)­(tmbdc)] n , as maroon block crystals (5.6 mg, 77%). Elemental Analysis: Found C, 52.87; H, 8.43 and N, 3.44; Calculated for C40H22CoN4O2­·27.79CH3OH: C, 52.87; H, 8.72; N, 3.64%.
elements.clean_text:
[CoNPy3(tmbdc)] n  Framework

NPy3 (5 mg, 1.05 × 10-5 mol), 2,3,5,6-tetramethylterephalic acid (7.00 mg, 3.15 × 10-5 mol), and cobalt(II) chloride hexahydrate (7.5 mg, 3.15 × 10-5 mol) were dissolved in a mixture of DMF (5 mL) and methanol (5 mL). The reaction mixture was heated to 60 °C at a rate of 0.1 °C/min and held at 60 °C for 48 h before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min to yield the framework, [Co(NPy3)(tmbdc)] n , as maroon block crystals (5.6 mg, 77%). Elemental Analysis: Found C, 52.87; H, 8.43 and N, 3.44; Calculated for C40H22CoN4O2⋅27.79CH3OH: C, 52.87; H, 8.72; N, 3.64%.

elements.content: All structures were collected at the Australian Synchrotron, Clayton, Victoria, on the MX1 and MX2 beamlines. A single crystal of the framework was coated in a thin film of paratone-N oil before being mounted on a ADSC Quantum 315r diffractometer employing Silicon Double Crystal monochromated Synchrotron radiation generated from the MX2 Beamline at the Australian Synchrotron in a stream of nitrogen at 100 K where the Blu-Ice graphical interface was used. The [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97, the [Co­(NPy3)­(dmbdc)­Cl] n was solved using SIR92 and [Co­(NPy3)­(tmbdc)] n was solved using superflip. All structures were refined using SHELXL-97 in WinGX. The SQUEEZE function in PLATON was used to treat the disordered solvent molecules present in the pores of the framework and to estimate the guest-accessible pore volumes. The non-hydrogen atoms in the asymmetric unit were modeled with anisotropic displacement parameters and a riding atom model with group displacement parameters was used for the hydrogen atoms. Reflections determined to be a result of the beamstop were removed from the refinements for the [Co­(NPy3)­(dmbdc)­Cl] n and [Co­(NPy3)­(tmbdc)] n structures. The [Co­(NPy3)­(tmbdc)] n structure was determined to have the presence of an inversion twin where the fraction of the inversion related component is 0.4. See ref for crystallographic details.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

All structures were collected at the Australian Synchrotron, Clayton, Victoria, on the MX1 and MX2 beamlines. A single crystal of the framework was coated in a thin film of paratone-N oil before being mounted on a ADSC Quantum 315r diffractometer employing Silicon Double Crystal monochromated Synchrotron radiation generated from the MX2 Beamline at the Australian Synchrotron in a stream of nitrogen at 100 K where the Blu-Ice graphical interface was used. The [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n  structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97, the [Co(NPy3)(dmbdc)Cl] n  was solved using SIR92 and [Co(NPy3)(tmbdc)] n  was solved using superflip. All structures were refined using SHELXL-97 in WinGX. The SQUEEZE function in PLATON was used to treat the disordered solvent molecules present in the pores of the framework and to estimate the guest-accessible pore volumes. The non-hydrogen atoms in the asymmetric unit were modeled with anisotropic displacement parameters and a riding atom model with group displacement parameters was used for the hydrogen atoms. Reflections determined to be a result of the beamstop were removed from the refinements for the [Co(NPy3)(dmbdc)Cl] n  and [Co(NPy3)(tmbdc)] n  structures. The [Co(NPy3)(tmbdc)] n  structure was determined to have the presence of an inversion twin where the fraction of the inversion related component is 0.4. See ref  for crystallographic details.

elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analysis was performed under a flow of nitrogen (0.1 L/min) on a TA Instruments Hi-Res or Discovery Thermogravimetric Analyzer from 25 to 600 °C at 1 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were obtained on a PANalytical X’Pert PRO Diffractometer producing Cu α (1.5406 Å) radiation, where the spectra were obtained with the lightly ground sample sealed in a glass capillary.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Characterization

General Details

Thermal gravimetric analysis was performed under a flow of nitrogen (0.1 L/min) on a TA Instruments Hi-Res or Discovery Thermogravimetric Analyzer from 25 to 600 °C at 1 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were obtained on a PANalytical X'Pert PRO Diffractometer producing Cu α (1.5406 Å) radiation, where the spectra were obtained with the lightly ground sample sealed in a glass capillary.

elements.content: UV/vis/NIR spectroscopy was performed on a Cary5000 spectrophotometer equipped with a Harrick Praying Mantis accessory, where dried BaSO4 was used for the baseline. Spectra are reported as the Kubelka–Munk transform, where F(R) = (1 – R)2/2R (R is the diffuse reflectance of the sample as compared to BaSO4).
elements.clean_text:
Solid State UV/vis/NIR

UV/vis/NIR spectroscopy was performed on a Cary5000 spectrophotometer equipped with a Harrick Praying Mantis accessory, where dried BaSO4 was used for the baseline. Spectra are reported as the Kubelka-Munk transform, where F(R) = (1 - R)2/2R (R is the diffuse reflectance of the sample as compared to BaSO4).

elements.content: Solid state electrochemical measurements were performed using a Bioanalytical Systems Epsilon Electrochemical Analyser. Argon was bubbled through solutions of 0.1 M [(n-C4H9)4N]­PF6/CH3CN. The cyclic voltammograms (CVs) were recorded using a glassy carbon working electrode (1.5 mm diameter), a platinum wire auxiliary electrode and an Ag/Ag+ wire quasi-reference electrode. Solid state samples were mounted on the glassy carbon working electrode by dipping the electrode into a paste made of the powder sample in acetonitrile. Ferrocene was added as an internal standard upon completion of each experiment. All potentials are quoted in mV versus Fc/Fc+.
elements.clean_text:
Solid State Electrochemistry

Solid state electrochemical measurements were performed using a Bioanalytical Systems Epsilon Electrochemical Analyser. Argon was bubbled through solutions of 0.1 M [(n-C4H9)4N]PF6/CH3CN. The cyclic voltammograms (CVs) were recorded using a glassy carbon working electrode (1.5 mm diameter), a platinum wire auxiliary electrode and an Ag/Ag+ wire quasi-reference electrode. Solid state samples were mounted on the glassy carbon working electrode by dipping the electrode into a paste made of the powder sample in acetonitrile. Ferrocene was added as an internal standard upon completion of each experiment. All potentials are quoted in mV versus Fc/Fc+.

The reaction mixture was heated to 60 °C at a rate of 0.1 °C/min and held at 60 °C for 48 h before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min to yield the framework, [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n , as maroon needle-like crystals (5.4 mg, 72%). Elemental analysis: Found C, 65.35; H, 4.95 and N, 8.01; Calculated for C37H26Cl­CoN4O2­·2CH3OH: C, 65.32; H, 4.78; N, 7.81%.

The reaction mixture was heated to 60 °C at a rate of 0.1 °C/min and held at 60 °C for 48 h before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min to yield the framework, [Co­(NPy3)­(dmbdc)­Cl] n , as maroon needle-like crystals (12 mg, 86%). cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Frameworks

[CoNPy3(bdc)Cl] n  Framework

NPy3 (5 mg, 1.05 × 10-5 mol), terephalic acid (5.23 mg, 3.00 × 10-5 mol), and cobalt(II) chloride hexahydrate (7.5 mg, 3.15 × 10-5 mol) were dissolved in a mixture of DMF (5 mL) and methanol (5 mL). The reaction mixture was heated to 60 °C at a rate of 0.1 °C/min and held at 60 °C for 48 h before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min to yield the framework, [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n , as maroon needle-like crystals (5.4 mg, 72%). Elemental analysis: Found C, 65.35; H, 4.95 and N, 8.01; Calculated for C37H26ClCoN4O2⋅2CH3OH: C, 65.32; H, 4.78; N, 7.81%.

[CoNPy3(dmbdc)Cl] n  Framework

NPy3 (10 mg, 2.10 × 10-5 mol), 2,5-dimethylterephalic acid (12.2 mg, 7.30 × 10-5 mol), and cobalt(II) chloride hexahydrate (15.0 mg, 7.30 × 10-5 mol) were dissolved in a mixture of DMF (5 mL) and methanol (5 mL). The reaction mixture was heated to 60 °C at a rate of 0.1 °C/min and held at 60 °C for 48 h before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min to yield the framework, [Co(NPy3)(dmbdc)Cl] n , as maroon needle-like crystals (12 mg, 86%). Elemental analysis: Found C, 65.01; H, 4.70 and N, 8.69; Calculated for C38H24ClCoN4O2⋅0.85DMF⋅1.77CH3OH: C, 65.01; H, 4.77; N, 8.69%.

[CoNPy3(tmbdc)] n  Framework

NPy3 (5 mg, 1.05 × 10-5 mol), 2,3,5,6-tetramethylterephalic acid (7.00 mg, 3.15 × 10-5 mol), and cobalt(II) chloride hexahydrate (7.5 mg, 3.15 × 10-5 mol) were dissolved in a mixture of DMF (5 mL) and methanol (5 mL). The reaction mixture was heated to 60 °C at a rate of 0.1 °C/min and held at 60 °C for 48 h before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min to yield the framework, [Co(NPy3)(tmbdc)] n , as maroon block crystals (5.6 mg, 77%). Elemental Analysis: Found C, 52.87; H, 8.43 and N, 3.44; Calculated for C40H22CoN4O2⋅27.79CH3OH: C, 52.87; H, 8.72; N, 3.64%.

cln_elements.content: The solid state structure of the [Co­(NPy3)­(dmbdc)­Cl] n framework was solved and refined in the monoclinic space group P21/n and was isostructural to [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n (ESI). Again, the dmbdc ligands act as pillars between the 2D zigzag layers containing the NPy3 ligand and Co2+ to form the 3D simple cubic net structure. The [Co­(NPy3)­(dmbdc)­Cl] n framework was also 3-fold interpenetrated but interestingly exhibited a significantly higher void accessible volume of 18.4% as calculated by PLATON when compared to the [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n structure (7.1%). The increase in the void accessible volume was presumably due to the increased steric bulk of the dmbdc ligand where the methyl groups may aid in holding the 3-fold interpenetrated networks apart from each other. TGA revealed a ∼15% mass loss <150 °C, corresponding to the loss of methanol from the pores of the framework (ESI).
cln_elements.clean_text: The solid state structure of the [Co(NPy3)(dmbdc)Cl] n  framework was solved and refined in the monoclinic space group P21/n and was isostructural to [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n  (ESI). Again, the dmbdc ligands act as pillars between the 2D zigzag layers containing the NPy3 ligand and Co2+ to form the 3D simple cubic net structure. The [Co(NPy3)(dmbdc)Cl] n  framework was also 3-fold interpenetrated but interestingly exhibited a significantly higher void accessible volume of 18.4% as calculated by PLATON when compared to the [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n  structure (7.1%). The increase in the void accessible volume was presumably due to the increased steric bulk of the dmbdc ligand where the methyl groups may aid in holding the 3-fold interpenetrated networks apart from each other. TGA revealed a ~15% mass loss <150 °C, corresponding to the loss of methanol from the pores of the framework (ESI).

crystal system.condition: unit cell has three edges of equal length and right angles between them

porosity.condition: solvent-accessible void space within the framework

decomposition temperature.type: gradual removal of coordinated water molecules

decomposition temperature.condition: loss of methanol from the pores

cln_elements.content: (a) Coordination mode around the Co2+ center, (b) three interpenetrated networks along the c axis, and (c) the 2D network containing the NPy3 ligand coordinated to Co2+ centers and the bridging bdc ligand forming the 3D network of the [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n framework.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination mode around the Co2+ center, (b) three interpenetrated networks along the c axis, and (c) the 2D network containing the NPy3 ligand coordinated to Co2+ centers and the bridging bdc ligand forming the 3D network of the [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n  framework.

cln_elements.content: Solid state structure of the [Co­(NPy3)­(tmbdc)] n framework showing the (a) asymmetric unit, (b) view along the a axis, (c) three interpenetrating (10,3b) nets comprising of the Co centers and NPy3 ligands, where the blue and red nets are crystallographically related and (d) the single network created by linkage of the interpenetrating (10,3b) nets through the Co centers by the tmbdc ligand.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Solid state structure of the [Co(NPy3)(tmbdc)] n  framework showing the (a) asymmetric unit, (b) view along the a axis, (c) three interpenetrating (10,3b) nets comprising of the Co centers and NPy3 ligands, where the blue and red nets are crystallographically related and (d) the single network created by linkage of the interpenetrating (10,3b) nets through the Co centers by the tmbdc ligand.

cln_elements.content: Solid state cyclic voltammograms of (a) [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n , (b) [Co­(NPy3)­(dmbdc)­Cl] n , and (c) [Co­(NPy3)­(tmbdc)] n in 0.1 M [(n-C4H9)4N]­PF6/CH3CN electrolyte at scan rates in the range 100–1000 mV/s. Potentials are reported vs the Fc/Fc+ couple where the arrow indicates the direction of the forward scan.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Solid state cyclic voltammograms of (a) [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n , (b) [Co(NPy3)(dmbdc)Cl] n , and (c) [Co(NPy3)(tmbdc)] n  in 0.1 M [(n-C4H9)4N]PF6/CH3CN electrolyte at scan rates in the range 100-1000 mV/s. Potentials are reported vs the Fc/Fc+ couple where the arrow indicates the direction of the forward scan.

cln_elements.content: Solid state UV/vis/NIR spectrum of [Co­(NPy3)­(bdc)­Cl] n , [Co­(NPy3)­(dmbdc)­Cl] n , [Co­(NPy3)­(tmbdc)] n , and their oxidized analogues over the range 5000–40000 cm–1.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Solid state UV/vis/NIR spectrum of [Co(NPy3)(bdc)Cl] n , [Co(NPy3)(dmbdc)Cl] n , [Co(NPy3)(tmbdc)] n , and their oxidized analogues over the range 5000-40000 cm-1.

metadata.title:
Controlling Interpenetration in Electroactive Co(II)
Frameworks Based on the Tris(4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)amine Ligand
